**Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u0.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to **Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14** (covenant of quiet enjoyment).

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2**.proposition: Venue is proper in the **Springfield District Court** because the Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in Springfield.

**Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway,.proposition: Electricity and proper wiring are essential services and conditions that a reasonable tenant would expect to be maintained in a habitable residential apartment.
**Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway,.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses an implied warranty of habitability and minimum standards under the State Sanitary Code, but it does not specifically identify electricity or proper wiring as essential services or conditions a reasonable tenant expects. The justice actually criticizes the majority’s broader, undefined habitability standard and would instead tie the landlord’s obligation to compliance with existing codes, whatever they require. Because the text never singles out electrical service or wiring, this opinion does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
**Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway,.relevant_excerpt: “The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail and to an extent never before incorporated in any statute. It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall ... let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit, for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking, or eating therein, which does not comply’ with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions.”

**Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, is obligated under **G.L. c. 186, § 14** and Massachusetts common law to ensure that the Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment is not substantially interfered with, including by failure to correct serious defects in utilities essential to the use of the premises.
**Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case does support a broad Massachusetts common-law principle that a landlord is responsible for substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment that are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord does, fails to do, or permits to be done, and may be liable even without intent. However, the decision does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it involve or focus on failure to correct serious defects in utilities essential to the premises; rather, it concerns noise from a lounge leased by the landlord. Thus it is only partial support at common law and does not support the full statutory proposition as stated.
**Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). ... Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.

**Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a **substantial interference** with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of leased premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, whether or not the landlord acts with malicious intent.
**Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the standard for interference with quiet enjoyment under both the common-law covenant and G.L. c. 186, § 14, and explains that more recent Massachusetts decisions impose liability when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is an interruption of the tenant’s rights, without requiring malicious or specific intent. The court explicitly states that the Legislature, by using the ‘quiet enjoyment’ language, incorporated these cases and that malicious intent is not required, at least where the landlord’s conduct is reckless and causes substantial interference. This aligns with the proposition that substantial interference suffices for breach of quiet enjoyment regardless of malicious intent.
**Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord, e.g., Katz v. Duffy, 261 Mass. 149 (1927), more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381-383 (1942)… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… [M]alicious intent is not necessary, and the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s.”

**Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: **Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)** (per curiam)
**Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A landlord’s **failure to maintain essential services** and building systems (including proper electrical service) in a way that substantially interferes with a tenant’s use of the premises can constitute a violation of **G.L. c. 186, § 14**.
**Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an essential service required by the State Sanitary Code—constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment and a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of the landlord’s financial inability. While the facts involve heat rather than electrical service, the reasoning is framed broadly in terms of failure to furnish an essential service that seriously impairs the character and value of the premises, so it logically extends to other essential building systems like electricity. The proposition’s specific reference to electrical service is not in the opinion, but its broader statement about essential services and substantial interference is supported.
**Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled … [to] a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

**Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847.proposition: A landlord’s **failure to maintain essential services** and building systems (including proper electrical service) in a way that substantially interferes with a tenant’s use of the premises can constitute a violation of **G.L. c. 186, § 14**.
**Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a statutory violation (the lead paint statute) automatically constitutes a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds that it does not. While the court reaffirms that negligent failures to repair known defects can violate § 14, it does not address essential services or electrical systems specifically, nor does it create or apply any rule about failure to maintain such services. Thus, it cannot be cited as direct authority for the proposition about essential services and electrical service under § 14.
**Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

**Eaton v. Federal Nat\u2019l Mortgage A.raw_text: **Eaton v. Federal Nat’l Mortgage Ass’n, 462 Mass. 569, 587–88 (2012)**
**Eaton v. Federal Nat\u2019l Mortgage A.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts residential lease and tenancy‑at‑will, and may also be expressly stated.
**Eaton v. Federal Nat\u2019l Mortgage A.case_name: Eaton v. Federal National Mortgage Ass'n
**Eaton v. Federal Nat\u2019l Mortgage A.support_reasoning: The Eaton opinion is about the validity of nonjudicial mortgage foreclosures and the meaning of “mortgagee” under Massachusetts foreclosure statutes. It does not discuss residential leases, tenancies‑at‑will, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment—implied or express. Therefore it cannot be relied on as authority for the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts residential lease and tenancy‑at‑will and may also be expressly stated.

**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts residential lease and tenancy‑at‑will, and may also be expressly stated.
**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass..support_reasoning: The case discusses an implied obligation arising from a lease—that the lessor refrain from acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises—and frames this in terms of quiet enjoyment, but it does not state that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts residential lease or tenancy‑at‑will. The opinion involves a commercial dental office lease and focuses on landlord liability for interference and nuisance, not on the universal implication of quiet enjoyment covenants in all residential or at‑will tenancies. It therefore does not support the specific breadth of the proposition claimed.
**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant…”

**G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u201312.proposition: Housing and sanitary codes form part of the standard of habitability and are relevant in evaluating whether quiet enjoyment has been breached.

**G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A**.proposition: Pursuant to **105 CMR 410.351, 410.251, and related provisions** of the State Sanitary Code (promulgated under **G.L. c. 111, § 127A**), landlords are required to maintain safe and functional electrical systems and provide adequate lighting and outlets in habitable rooms.

**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: **Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)**
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have found violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where landlords fail to address significant building or utility defects after notice.
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does address breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but not in the context of building or utility defects. Instead, it concerns the landlord’s failure to take measures against pervasive criminal drug activity by third parties in common areas. The court’s reasoning and holding focus on inaction regarding unlawful conduct, not on failure to repair or address significant building or utility defects after notice, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

**Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 404 Mass. 1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have found violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where landlords fail to address significant building or utility defects after notice.
**Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 404 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether an award of litigation costs is a “judgment for the payment of money” that bears postjudgment interest under Mass. G. L. c. 235, § 8. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, residential conditions, utility or building defects, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it provides no authority for the claimed proposition that Massachusetts courts find violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where landlords fail to address significant building or utility defects after notice.
**Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 404 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: “The sole issue before us is whether the defendants…are entitled to postjudgment interest on an award of costs… We must determine, therefore, whether an award of costs is a ‘judgment for the payment of money,’ within the meaning of G. L. c. 235, § 8… [W]e conclude that an award of costs is a ‘judgment for the payment of money’ under G. L. c. 235, § 8.”

**Williams v. Parkell, 29 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have found violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where landlords fail to address significant building or utility defects after notice.
**Williams v. Parkell, 29 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Miles v. Planning Board of Millbury
**Williams v. Parkell, 29 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns subdivision control, planning board approval, and the validity of conditions attached to a definitive subdivision plan. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, building or utility defects, or a landlord’s failure to repair after notice. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the proposition about Massachusetts courts finding covenant-of-quiet-enjoyment violations in such circumstances.
**Williams v. Parkell, 29 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The definitive subdivision plan before us, called “Clearview Estates,” proposes to place some 276 duplex houses on 130 acres of land in Millbury now used as a golf course. A previous version of the plan was disapproved by the planning board... After public hearings, the planning board voted to approve the plan, subject to thirteen “conditions.” Miles, an abutter, filed an appeal... From a judgment declaring that the approval of the plan by the planning board did not exceed the authority of the board, the abutter appeals to this court.

**Commonwealth v. DeCotis, 366 Mass. 234.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks appropriate **equitable and injunctive relief**, including an order requiring Defendant to promptly and properly repair the electrical system to restore safe and functional electricity to the affected bedroom, to the extent such relief is within this Court’s power in conjunction with the statutory claim.
**Commonwealth v. DeCotis, 366 Mass. 234.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that equitable and injunctive relief, including affirmative repair-type orders, is available in conjunction with a statutory (Chapter 93A‑type) claim. DeCotis squarely holds that courts, proceeding in equity under G.L. c. 93A, possess full traditional equitable power to fashion effective remedies beyond mere prohibitory injunctions, including affirmative obligations and restitution, and characterizes the 1969 amendment as merely clarifying that existing equitable authority. This directly supports the notion that a trial court may order affirmative injunctive relief (such as repairs) ancillary to a statutory consumer‑protection claim, so long as within its general equitable power.
**Commonwealth v. DeCotis, 366 Mass. 234.relevant_excerpt: “We believe that, as originally enacted, G. L. c. 93A granted full authority to the courts to use their traditional equity power to fashion decrees to remedy the wrong complained of and to make the decree effective… This traditional power includes the right to require that funds be placed in escrow… and includes the right to place on the wrongdoer the expense of finding persons entitled to funds… We view the 1969 amendment to § 4 of G. L. c. 93A as clarifying the authority of the court, but not increasing it.”

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: Statutory interest from the date of the interference or from such other date as the Court deems just, pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
